messages: 42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (19:36): webben, you are Benjamin Hawkes-Lewis?

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:43): a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d: I committed code for releasing memory in the HTML5 parser earlier today. I expect the code for releasing element nodes to change in the future to make it possible to dispatch memory release request to a different thread.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:44): s/request/requests/
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:47): a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d: I hope the code for releasing local names can remain as-is. I'll have to check if atoms are thread-safe in Gecko.

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:48): (I'm not really satisfied with the manual nature of the memory management and having to know where stuff gets released, but alternatives seemed like overkills.)
a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (19:51): I've only just gotten back to looking at the code, the first assumption that the code makes is that unicode is stored as utf-16.
a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (19:52): For Ruby, at least, I'd like to use utf-8.

a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (19:53): My immediate plans at to try to compile the generated code outside of Mozilla, stubbing everything I need to to get it to compile (not execute or even link, simply compile).  That will give me an initial list of things I need to worry about.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:54): I guess I should write some kind of document pointing out the memory ownership assumptions

a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (19:57): don't worry too much about it, I'll discover what I need to from the code, when I see things that need addressed, I'll discuss them with you, and then over time we will evolve this into something that can handle multiple environments... at that point documentation would be helpful.
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (20:18): a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d: there is a C HTML5 parser around which assumes UTF-8 :)
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (20:22): http://www.netsurf-browser.org/projects/hubbub/
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (20:22): I spent my summer working on it
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (20:22): it hasn't had a formal release yet either
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (20:22): but it is being used as a parser in a browser for minority OSs
a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (20:23): good choice of license
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (20:43): http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=XHTML&diff=262789758&oldid=prev
78885357e970c69de0c33081760a04c9 (20:46): whatwg has almost always referred to it as HTML5
78885357e970c69de0c33081760a04c9 (20:46): and w3c has almost said HTML 5
78885357e970c69de0c33081760a04c9 (20:46): why that needs to be corrected in an wikipedia article is beyond me
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (20:47): 78885357e970c69de0c33081760a04c9: it's a convenient way to also brush off the observation that XHTML 1.2 is not chartered
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (20:48): whatever happened to xhtml2 rebranding?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:49): 78885357e970c69de0c33081760a04c9: No, we haven't.
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (20:49): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, and changing xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2002/06/xhtml2/" to xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"
78885357e970c69de0c33081760a04c9 (20:50): i see that the whatwg specs do in fact have the space as well

a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:50): 78885357e970c69de0c33081760a04c9: WHATWG has for years called it Web Applications 1.0, and the combination of that with WF2 has often been called "HTML 5". The spec noted it was often called that too
78885357e970c69de0c33081760a04c9 (20:50): though I swore they didnt always
78885357e970c69de0c33081760a04c9 (20:50): not that this matters one damn bit
78885357e970c69de0c33081760a04c9 (20:50): fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98: that's a great question... I was lead to believe that a consensus had been reached in 2007 to undertake that work...
78885357e970c69de0c33081760a04c9 (20:50): perhaps i misunderstood
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (20:51): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, I'm also confused by the removal of .xml when .html and .htm are retained.
78885357e970c69de0c33081760a04c9 (20:52): huh, what happened to: http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml12
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:52): 78885357e970c69de0c33081760a04c9: AFAIK they never published a WD‚Ä¶
78885357e970c69de0c33081760a04c9 (20:53): yeah but there were editor's draft...
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:53): 78885357e970c69de0c33081760a04c9: That won't be a TR
78885357e970c69de0c33081760a04c9 (20:53): then the editor's draft is wrong
78885357e970c69de0c33081760a04c9 (20:53): as it points to that URL
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:53): what ED?
78885357e970c69de0c33081760a04c9 (20:54): well there this: http://www.w3.org/MarkUp/2008/ED-xhtml12-20081023/xhtml12.html
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:54): Ah, the latest stable version link always points to such a URL even when it doesn't exist
78885357e970c69de0c33081760a04c9 (20:54): there's actually a newer one here: http://www.w3.org/MarkUp/2008/ED-xhtml12-20081223/
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (20:55): they removed the flaming subtitle, it seems
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:56): what subtitle?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (20:56): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: meaningful, accessible XHTML
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (20:56): or something like that
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (20:56): ah

42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (21:01): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, there's a section in the Talk page on the Wikipedia article about that, too: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:XHTML#Change_title_for_XHTML_1.2
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (21:02): it lists the entry on this page as how you find the XHTML 1.2 draft: http://www.w3.org/MarkUp/Drafts/#xhtml12
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (21:03): (the date is what you click to get the spec)
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (21:04): hmm, XHTML Media Types updated: http://www.w3.org/MarkUp/2009/ED-xhtml-media-types-20090107/
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:15): needs a word that means "not introspection".
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:15): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: How about using two words?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:15): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: No.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:17): extraspection? :-)
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (21:18): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554, what's the context?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:18): Introspectionless?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:19): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: It's s/a/o/, but no, that's still more specific. There are things that are neither.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:19): Antiintrospectionarianism?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:19): 42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9: tag for blog, to separate display of posts on the home page up
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:19): 42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9: (Most of those tagged with introspection are also tagged with lust :))
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (21:20): outgoing?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:20): 42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9: That too leaves things that are neither
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (21:20): I think I understand what you're trying to convey and are similarly struggling to figure out the word. :)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:20): (think of code, that isn't really observing anything)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:21): 42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9: http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/introspection :)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:21): 42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9: Anything that isn't that.
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (21:21): perhaps the absence of the introspection tag is sufficient to indicate it is "not introspection"?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:21): 42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9: Then I have the issue of a column header.
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (21:22): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554, do you have a demo page with placeholder text for it I could see?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:23): 42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9: does sftp:/ a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554:/dev/head work for you? :)
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (21:24): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554, I may have uninstalled the only app I had which supported sftp...
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:24): 42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9: Then you have the issue of reading my head, though.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:24): thinks 42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 missed the joke
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (21:25): gives up.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:28): tries to come up with a sample of what he wants, then realizes he can't decide how to mark it up ;P
